div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.PO, Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday.

div.head: St. George's Carrison Church.
div.p: Parado service tomorrow at 9:30a.m. Canon Ward, assisted by the Rev. C. H. V. Gollmer, is noting chaplain (Church of England) to the forces.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to August amounted to 746,017 tons, as compared with 59,859 tons in the same period last year.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bailetin recorded a fresh caso at Alexandria, the patient being a European woman living in the Attareen. Today's bulletin is a clean sheet.

div.head: Khartoum Fire.
div.p: The recent big fire at Khartoum was due to a lighted match dropped by a careless farmer. The total loss of Mr. Capatos in estimated at LB 5,000: half of this represented new stock.

div.head: Hashiah Smuggling.
div.p: A quantity of hashish was confiscated by the Alexandria City Police on Thursday night in the neighborhood of Mafrouza. The two anglers who were caught with the hashish are well known to the police.

div.head: Imperial Anniversary.
div.p: The Emperor Prancie-Joseph was born on the 18th August, 1830, and the anniversary of his birthday was celebrated to-day at Cairo, and Alexandria by official receptions at the Austro-Hungarian Consulates.

div.head: Bakshiah and Freedom.
div.p: The ex-post office clerk rt Abon Hamal who obtained the enm of LE 40 by means of a fictitious telegraphic order on the Cairo Post Office escaped during his examination. Bakshish, it is feared, facilitated his flight.

div.head: Three Persons Drowned.
div.p: Two days ago, the bodies of three natives, including a litt's child, were found by the Cairo police. Two had been drowned in the Nile and one in the Ismailia Canal. Their corpses were taken to hospital for postmortem examination.

div.head: Grievances Against Railways.
div.p: The Government has appointed a Commission to enquire into the grievances of the inhabitants of Zaitoon and Matarish against the State Railways for having placed barriers at the level crossings which encroach on the road to their detriment.

div.head: Attempted Suicide.
div.p: Io Clot Bey street, Cairo, on Thursday even- ing, a drunken Greek attempted to abide by throwing himself down in front of a tram. The driver, however, drew up in time to prevent the realization of what a contemporary describes as a "singular idea."

div.head: Accident at Ramieh.
div.p: An Italian, 26 years of age, in the service of the Alexandria Gas Company, was at work yesterday repairing some wire on a lofty pole in Ramelb, when he lost his balance and fell to the ground, a distance of twenty meters. It is doubtful whether he will survive.

div.head: Rescue From Drowning.
div.p: An Italian lady who was bathing in Stanley Bay yesterday got out of her depth and was in imminent danger of drowning, when her dangerous position was noticed by Coastguardsman Aly Giker, who immediately went to the lady's assistance and brought her safely ashore.

div.head: Egypt Lost Dark.
div.p: Mr. Joseph B. McNamara, of Cairo, chief electrical engineer of the Egyptian Railways Company, announces that Americans pay three times as much for their electric lighting as I charged in Egypt. That good old familiar phrase, "Darkest Egypt," seems to have out- lived its justification. ("Pittsburgh Press").

div.head: Crushed to Death
div.p: A shocking accident took place in the Minet el-Basal quarter of A'exsedris yesterday. Four natives, a man and three women, were working in a corn store when they were buried beneath a number of sacks of barley. 010 of the women were crushed to death and the others were so badly hurt that they had to "be taken to hospital.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: MThe British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria.

div.head:
THE SULTAN'S ILLNESS
HIS MAJESTY AND THE SELAMLIK
div.p: (PROM OUR CORRESPONDENT) CONSTANTINOPLE Angest 12. H. I. M. The Saltan was unable to attend Salamlik on Priday last, owing to serious indisposition. This is only the second location in the course of his thirty four years' reign on which hie Majesty has failed to attend public worship on Friday; the first being twenty sight years ago. A painful silment from which the Sultan has long been suffering has latterly become more acute, and on July 29th, his Majesty's condition gave rise to grave anxiety. On bPriday, the third of this month, the august patient had regained sufficient strength to allow for his proceeding as usual to the Hamidié Mosque. Though the audiences and receptions which his Majesty generally holde on his return to Yildiz Palace after Selamlik were postponed, it was generally believe that the Baltan was on the high way to a complete recovery, but unfortunately these hopes were not realized, as on Sunday, the 6th inst., the directing symptoms recurred. No official communication was made to the loos! Pross nor any comment permitted, and it was there- in fire with no little anrpries and alarm that toon Priday last the polio saw the troops which h had left barracks as nenal to attend Selamlik being stopped on the way. and ordered to return. For an hour or two there was a light panis on the local Bourse, but restoring private information soon put an end to this. The news obtained from Palaco circles since Friday has continued to be favorable, and in the opinion of the best able to judge. His Majesty, though off ring acutely for the tims boinz, is in no serena's danger and should soon roover his customary good health. CONSTANTINOPLE, August 17. The Saltan attended the Selamlik: the al ceremonial was performed. (Reuter) CONSTANTINOPLE, August 17. The Saltan has attended the Selamlik (Tavar) to-day. The "Levant Herald" publishes the following letter:- "His Imperial Majesty the Sultan, my Aa- gast Master, greatly appreciated your Excel- lancy's good wishes conveyed through your first dragomar. "By Order of my August Sovereign I have the pleasure to announce to your Excellency that His Imperial Majesty has completely recovered. "His Majesty looks forward to shortly receiv ing your Excellency and verbally expressing his satisfaction."

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS
div.p: An American contemporary saya a propon of the Capitulations that, as far as the United States is encerred, they will probably be abdicated with roadie oss and good grace, and the European signatories will abdicate it with what grace they may. For England is in Egypt as master and to stay, and the present recommendation of Lord Cromer is simply a step in the consolidation of her power and a simpli- fication of her manner of government.

div.head: OLD OFFENDERS
div.p: In 1904, 7,295 old offenders were shown imprisoned in Egypt, whereas 5,882 are only registered during the past year. However, far from any diminution, the number of old offenders is ever increasing and the apparent decrosse is on account of the Merkez Tribunal dealing with accused without any reference to the Casier Judiciaire. Numbers of prisoners are those shown without antecedents who are in reality old jail birds. This opinion is confirmed by the fact that in offenses against property (which are cot as a rale dealt with by the Merker Coarte) there has been a considerable increase, the figures for the two years (1905 and 1904) being 9,947 and 9,431 respectively.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FIRST AID- SOCIETY.
div.p: At a meeting held in Cairo on Tuesday evening on the premises of the Italian Work- men's Society the promoters of the International First Aid cinty appointed a provisional committee to draw up plans for ensuring the proper working of the Society. This committee is composed of Dr. A. Spallangon, Mears. G. Rampazzo, A. Altano, G. Biagiotti, G.Donadio, A. Boolari, C. Brigido, and P. Vasai.

div.head: SKIN DISEASE IN PRISON.
div.p: As ungal, daring the past year, there has been a large amount of skin disease, favar, scabies, ets, says Coles Pashs. Scabies has hoen prevalent especially in Alexandria, Zagazig, and Cairo. The Upper Egypt prisoners do not appear to be attacked by macb. Since attention has been called to it, it has been found that a reliable number of prisoners come in suffering from it, and this is specially the esee in Alexandria.

div.head:
COAL IN EGYPT
IMPORTANT STATEMENT
div.p: Some time ago we dealt with the commercial importance of any discovery of payable coal in Egypt. Johnson Pasba has set forth as follows anupaber of reasons, for supposing that coal does exist in the country: 1. Conditions now existing support the idea that in early geological times there was a much bigger mountain range along the Red Sox coast than now, and a deep sheltered depression to the west, favorable to forest growth. 2. The fact that there is no outcrop, or the alleged fact of there being no onterop of the carboniferous atrata between the Nubian sandstones and the granites, is no evidence that there may not be carboniferous deposits low down in the bottom of the depression. 3. At the same time, ho believer, it is recorded in the Institut Egyption that tree carboniferous strata ontario to the north-west of Jebel Zeit. 4. A German geologi- enl map published a good many years ago, obtainable at Stanford's, shows the carboniferous deposits ontoropping in a line crossing the Sinai Peninsula some distance north ofSuez, and running up the valley of the Jordan. 5. Very narrow beds of cos! (about skin. thick) were certainly found by Nefinger, who bored at a point near Radonis, opposite Edfa, some 70 yosra ago. Also many beds of black shale and loaf beds. This was confirmed by the Sacre- ries two years ago. 6. Lignite was found at no great depth at Am Redham; east of Gurgeh, and in the Wady Kens. 7. Samples of pyrites, coated with weathered coal, have been repeat- edly brought to our correspondent from the Sinai Peninsula by Bedouins, who believe there is a large black area where they pick these up.

div.head:
EGYPT'S ABORIGINES
A NUBIAN ORIGIN
div.p: Thecovery last season of a great number of pot by Mr. Garatang at Kostaman, in Nabis, introduces a new problem into the discussion of Egyptian origins. Many of these are of the black and red type, and bear the obvions imitation of basket-work and other attempts at decoration which have hitherto been considered characteristic of the First Dynasty; and the question therefore arises whether we are to look, upon Nabia as one of the homes of the Egyptian abori- gines. Although Mr. Garstang has not yet committed himself on this point, there is much to be said for it; but the unprejudiced observer would perhaps rather see in it a Warning against attaching too much faith to the evidence of pottery as a means of dating. Among the other remarkable finds of Mr. Garstang in Nobis was a completely andis- turbed burial at Daken (the ancient Pre Lobis), containing some Eighteenth Dynasty scarabe and incised pottery. The tomb was built with stone chambers and a roof, although situated in the high desert: bat the corpse was in the "contracted" position once thought peculiar to the "New" or prehistorie race, and would certainly have been put down to this period bad it not been for the dated objects found with it. Nor does this instance of the sporadio survival in Egypt of certain customs stand alone. At the exhibition of Mr. Garstang's finds in Liverpool are to be seen another find from Kostamneb, a kneading-trough, or slightly. hallowed first stone, whereon some (possibly) prehistoric woman was accustomed to roll her broad. Behind it is to be seen the wooded model of a woman engaged in this occupation with an exactly similar atone-a model found in a tomb of the Twelfth Dynasty; while by its side is a photograph, taken by Mr. Garstang, a Nabian girl of the present day performing the same note with exactly similar materials. When customs and, in a double sonas, fashion in utensils that persist at in- tervals of more than 7,000 years, it is plain that no very cogent argument can be drawn from the form or style of things so easily made and imitated as clay pots.

div.head:
EGYPT'S DANGER
THE NATIVE ARMY
div.p: In considering the strength of our defenses in Egypt the great difficulty lies, says the Cairo Correspondent of a London contemporary, in not knowing to what extent the Egyptian Army could be relied on in the event of trouble t arising from fanaticism, that is to say, whether religion would be stronger than discipline. The Egyptian Army consists of the following troope: Sixsqadroneof Cavalry, six Mountain Batteries, the Camel Corps, and seventeen battalions of Infantry, of which six are Sudanese. This force amounts to, approximately, 10,000 men, and is stationed for the most art in Upper Egypt. The squadrons, batteries, and companies are commanded by English officers with native officers ander them. Recruiting is by con- soription, and the conscript has to serve five years with the colors and five years on the reserve; so that the Army could be mobilized and all the Reservists called up it could be raised to 20,000 men in war time. Most of the efficere attached to the Egyptian Army are inclined to believe that the greater part of the Army would remain loyal, particularly the Badacore battalions, but that the Reservists, who have returned to their homes and come again under the influence of their friends and relatives, could not be relied on. Never- theless, this is a problem, which cannot be solved until the occasion arises. Are we employing a large staff of our officers in training an Army which is going to help us to protect our interests, or are we turning out 20,000 trained men every ten years who may even- tually endeavor to drive out of the country!

div.head: FIRE IN CAIRO
div.p: A fire broke out at two o'clock yesterday morning in a grocer's shop in the Tewfik Ish district of Cairo, but thanks to the prompt arrival of the Fire Brigade and the efficacy with which its members worked, it was very promptly extinguished. Some delay was caused at the commencement by the difficulty which was experienced in finding the nearest fire cook, which was some fifty meters away from the scene of the fire, and in the meantime several tins et petroleum caught fire, which considerably increased the force of the conflagra- tion. The engine, however, soon got into play, and the flames were quickly subdued. The extent of the damage has not yet been estimated.

div.head: THE GALLICOPOULO AFFAIR
div.p: The preliminary inquiry instituted into the tragic death of a female servant of Mr. Galli- couple, of Cairo, who is accused of having placed boiling eggs in the armpits of the unfortunate girl with a view to extorting the confession of a theft, has been conoladed by the Greek Consul General. The report will be sent immediately to Athens and, we understand, the socused will be brought up for trial before the Court of Assises which will meet at Alexandria early in December.

div.head: "RIOT" IN ALEXANDRIA
div.p: A Cairo morning newspaper in to-day's face- gives the following information under the above headline: A serious riot took place in the Labbane quarter, Alexandria, on Thursday evening between a number of natives. Two men were wounded., Several arrests have been made." On enquiry at the Alexandria Governorate this morning who were informed that this information was untrue.

div.head: "ARE WE FANATICAL?"
div.p: A carinos commentary on the dimension as to the existence of fanaticism in Egypt is afforded by an incident which occurred in Cairo on Thursday last. A sheik, wearing a turban of unusually large dimensions, colleott ed a crowd of low class natives and began to harangos them, invoking blessings on the t Caliph and praying for his triumph and the confounding of the unbelievers. The audience listened with patients to a lengthy distorta tion, and finally their patience was exhausted. One of them went boldly up to him and dealt him a blow in the face. His example was followed by several others, and our sheik, deeming discretion the better part of valor, at once took to his heels, pursued by an angry mob.

div.head: MANSOURAH MUNICIPAL FIRE ENGINE
div.p: A rush, a shriek, a terrible note, Like fiends of hell set free: Followed by men and shouting boys, Screaming aloud in their glee. Hooting and screeching, it rattles along People start out of their beds, Wondering that, all the noise and the throng. Does not drive them, off their heads, The fire engine off to work at a rate, To a fire in the town But arrives too late; so returns in state: In spite of Moody's frown. With screams of triumph, and shrieks of delight: At having no work to do: With crowds of boys, running with all their might It makes enough noise for two. Tis à noted fact, when it does not shirk And late on the scene arrives The hose will not squirt, the pumps will not work, Through to save a set of lives What matters it though, they laugh and they crow, At all these disasters all Tet the old horses born, for you must know, The return is the best of all.

div.head:
UNREST IN EGYPT
AMERICAN OPINION
div.p: From the "New York Tribune":-It would be injudicious to assume that the pesce of the world is endangered by the unrest which undeniably prevails in the Bayp tian delta, or that the peace of Barope is threatened. Time was when such might have been the case. That was when the status of Egypt in relation to the European Powers was As yet undefined. But now there is no un- certainty on that point. Great Britain has a free hand in Egypt, and her policy and actions there will not be challenged by any other Power. The worst that can happen is that Great Britain will be compelled to put forth more of her strength for the control of Egypt. Bach a necessity, should it arise, would be regrettable, but it would not be embarrassing. The emergency could be successfully met-mach more easily, we imagine, than was that of 1889. With so competent a statesman as Bir Edward Grey in the Poreign Office, and with the veteran Lord Cromer at Cairo, the British mind will probably remain tranquil on that subject, though demand fing that there shall be a constant and ample upholding of the hands of those to whom is committed the maintenance of British authority along the Nile.

div.head:
MR. RENE CARTON DE WIART
A BELIGIUM TRIBUTE
div.p: The well-known official of the Egyptian Prisons Department, Mr. René Carton de Wiart, receives the following appreciative notice in the columns of the "Bourse d'An- vers": Parmi les noms de nos compatriotes établis A l'étranger et auxquels l'ordre de Léopold vient d'être conféré, figure le nom de M. René Carton de Wiart bey, lieutenant-colonel dans l'armée égyptienne. Après s'être engagé, à l'âge de 16 ans, comme volontaire an Se régiment des gulder, M. René Carton de Wiart quitte l'armée belge en 1891 pour prendre de service en Egypte. Il participe, sous les ordres de Kitobener, aux campagnes contre les Mahdistes et à la pacification du Soudan. Il est à diriger lui-même, en plein désert, des expéditions à la poursuite de bandes de brigands qui inquiétaient les indi- gènes de la vallée de Nil. Au cours des grandes épidémies de choléra, il y a quelques années, il fut obligé d'organiser le service sanitaire dans les villages du Delta et d'inspecter dans la suite les mesures prises en vue de l'hygiène publique. Il exerce aujourd'hui les notations de gouvernement de Tourab, et a dans son ressort le service des prisons qui sont occupés en Egypte à des travaux en plein air, tels que ceux des carrières et des irrigations. Il a fondé dans son district diverses institutions, notamment des écoles pour l'amélioration dans. sort des indigènes, des soldats et des prisonniers. Ben Altesse le Khédive l'a diocé an grade de bey, qui n'est sooordé qué très rarement and der étrangers. M. René Carton de Wiart est le frère de l'honorable député de Bruxelles et secrétaire du roi.

div.head:
NEW HENDERSON LINER
LAUNCH OF THE S.S. AVA AT DUNBARTON
div.p: On the 8th inst., Messrs. Wm. Denny and Brothers launobed the steel screw steamer Ava for Moesta. P. Henderson and Co. 's Glas- Row, Liverpool, and Rangoon service. The Ava, like her sister ships the Tender and Martaban, has been constructed to the highest classification, and under the special survey of the British Corporation. Her principal Himen- sions are Length 410 feet, breadth 62 foot, and depth 30 ft. 9 in., and she is expected to attain a rate of speed which will enable her to accomplish the parade to Rangoon in under 30 days. The accommodation for passengers is fitted on the bridge deck. amidships, and consists of large airy two and three-berth rooms furnished in the most approved fashion, a noticeable improvement being the addition of an electric fan in each cabin. The dining saloon situated at the fore end of the bridge deck is in a large deok house framed in polished bard wood with bird's-eye maple panels, and upholstered in blas velvet, the carpets and curtains being in abados to matob. The tables are so arranged that passengers dine in small parties, an arrangement that finds favor with the traveling' publio.. On the shade deck above, are the smoking and ladies' rooms, both being artistically framed in polished hardwoods. There is ample lavatory accommodation, spray and plange baths being provided. Over the entire ship it is noticeable the care the owners Have given to secure the maximum of comfort for their passengers, special care having been taken with the ventilation, so that the beat of Red Sea passages may be mitigated as much as possible. In order to deal with bulky picoss of cargo the vowel is constructed on the belt pillar and girder principle, which does away with round stanchions and leaves olear holda The veel has no less than 18 derricks, all having an out-reach of fally 8 fest over the ship's side, the lifts ranging up to 20 bos, o that cargo of practically any weight and balk may be conveniently handled. A steam wind- lass with warping winch on the poop enables the vastel to be expeditiously handled in port. There is a complete installation of electric light on the 'Canon trio' system fitted by the builders. The installation includes masthead, ide and cargo lights, also a searah light to enable the vessel to navigate the Beer Canal at night. She saila on her first voyage on the 4th October,

div.head:
RUSSIAN REIGN OF TERROR
AUTHORITIES POWERLESS
SOLDIERS ATTACK JEWS
div.p: WARSAW, August 17. After the disturbances on Wednesday the soldiers, in the evening, attacked the Jews, killing or wounding 250 of them. (Roster) ST. PETERSBURG, August 17. The reign of terror is general throughout Russia. The police are powerless and the Government is incapable of dealing with the situation. (Reuter) WARSAW August 17. A street boy yesterday evening threw a petard into a crowd of pilgrims here and wounded two of them, whereupon an infantry patrol rushed up and fired a volley into the midst of the crowd, wounding 28 persons. (7.)

div.head:
EARTHQUAKE AT VALPARAISO
SERIOUS DAMAGE DONE
div.p: SERIOUS DAMAGE DONE VALPARAISO, August 17. An earthquake has taken place here. It was at first thought to be most serious and similar to that of San Francisco; this, however, seems to be an exaggeration, although some damage has been done and a panic occurred. (Reuter) PARIS, August 17. It is reported from Valparaiso that serious earthquakes have taken place. It is feared that there are numerous victims. (Hvar)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: It is officially intimated that the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, Brevet Colonel G.R.F. Smith commanding, with details for various regiments in Egypt, will embark on the 88. Sicilia at Sonthampton boats the 27th Septem- ber for Cairo, where the Coldstreamers are to be stationed prior to disbandment. The Sicilia will reach Alexandris on the 11th October and leave the following day with the last Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers on board for Malta. Arriving at Valletta on the 15th October, she will leave the same day for England with the 1st Battalion Rifle Brigade, bound for Belfast. The sossey for a captain in the 16th Inniskilling Dragoons, caused by the death of the ill-fated Captain Ball, has been filloi by the promotion of Lieutenant J.W.F. Tarleton. Captain Tarleton received his first appointment in the laniskillings from the Thames Division Submarine Miners (Militia) in November, 1899, and saw considerable service in the South African War of 1500-62,including the operations in Orange River Colony, and the Transvaal and Cape Colony (Queen's medal with three clasps, King's medal with two clasps). Major R. G. T. B-ker Carr, Rifle Brigade, serving latterly with the Rifle Depot, Win- chester, has taken his retired pay after over 18 years' service in the "Greenjackets." He was aide de camp to the Indian Viceroy from July, 1897, to November, 1903. Two subalterns of the 20 h Hoars have just been promoted to captaincies-Captains A. W. Jennings Bratayley and J. C. Bott-after the exceptionally long subaltern service of eleven years and a-half and ten years and night months respectively. Captain Jennings Bramly, who is presently serving with the Khedive's Army, entered the Royal Neots, Grays in March, 1895, and the same year transferred to the 1st King's Dragoon Guards and the 20th Hussars in succession. From September, 1902, till September, 1934, he was employed with the King's African Rifles, and on the expiration of this two years' tour, joined the Khedive's Army. He is presently employed as Junior Inspector of the Mongols Province, with the rank of Bimbashi. Captains H. C. Warre, D. 8. O, A. R. Leith; Lieutenants R A. Bradford, P. L Pardoe, C. V. L. Poe, and A. J. Hanter, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has passed the examination for promotion to the next higher rank. Lieutenant H. Beaumont, Laroshire Pari lists, has been seconded for service with the Egyptian Army. The order for the 1st Battalion the Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment to proceed from Malta to Belfast in the coming trooping season has been canceled, and instead the 2nd Battalion Royal Sussex Regiment, now in Crete, will replace the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in the Ulster hospital. It may be of interest to add that the 1st Battalion of the Royal Sussex Regiment, when raised in 1702, was raised at Belfast, by the then Barl of Donegal, and for a considerable period it was kabwn as the Belfast Regiment. The 2nd Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps will move from Ranikhet to Jubbulpore in the coming cold season. The practice of non-commissioned officers And men wearing the new peaked cap for walking ont purpose is to be discontinued until the cap is generally issued to the army. It seems that a large number of these capes were promised privately by the wearers. Since Lord Charles Beresford took over the command of the Mediterranean Fleet it has improved greatly in gannery. The brilliant performance of the destroyer Brazzer has attracted considerable attention in naval circles. The gunners of this destroyer, firing with the 6-pounder quick firing gun, hit the mark 46 times out of 58 roads, and six bits out of eight with the 12-pounder. The cruiser Barham with her 4.7 guns made 42 hits in 58 rounds, and the Venus 78 hits in 96 rounde-a great improvement in both since last year. The first class battleship Montagu, which has been lost to the fighting strength of the Lavy by the decision of the Admiralty not to expend farther money in attempting to alve what was a rock from the first- hereby confirming our forecast of a week -go-represents a loss of £1,046,992, which was her original cost when she was built at Devonport in 1903. During the salvage operations, a further sum of £60,000 was spent on her. The Montagu had a displace- ment of 14,000, a speed of 18.8 knots, and she carried an armament of four 12-inch guns, twelve 6-inch guns, and 21 smaller gane, and a crew of 750. Her maiden commission was spent on the Mediterranean Station. If Parliament were sitting the Icas of the Montage would provide the material for the most searching interrogations as to whether it was a contingency taken into consideration whos the naval shipbuilding programme was decided on. Naval experts do not at all like the naval policy of the Government. They spent the sounds of their two-power standard theory, and the Prime Minister's rejection of a possible combination of France and Germany against us in regarded as a fat one piece of optimism, and an ignoring of the elementary truths that there is nothing more probable in international affairs than the unexpected. When Parliament wobbles, nomervas questions on the enbhost will be a-ked for the purposes of elaci latin what the two power standard really is. The fact that, both Germany and France, on the admission of the Secretary of the Admiralty, are building ships faster than we are not considered reassuring. Meanwhile our navy is one first-class battleship less effective by the loss of the Montagu.

div.head:
THE SUDAN.
CRUSADE AGAINST MOSQUITOS
div.p: The first report issued from the Wellcome Research Laboratories of the Gordon Memorial College, Khartoum, shows the great im- portance of this institution as a center from which practical advantage is being taken of accorals scientific investigation and the utilizing of such. knowledge for the improvement of the sanitary condition of the inhabitants of the country. The volume, which is beautifully illustrated by photographs and drawings, is largely taken up with the results of researches bearing on the different species of mosquitoes, biting and noxious insects other than mosquitoes, and interests and vegetable parasites injurious to europe. Although for the most part the report, owing to the technical details, can only be appreciated to the fall by those acquainted with the abstrese terms of the entomologist and people possessed of expert knowledge, yet there is much of interest to the general reader. The most interesting chapter in this respect is dealing with the organization of a morgnito brigade towards the end of 1903. Dr. Balfour, the director of the laboratories, having classified the species of mosquitoes found in Khartoum and made a general survey of their breeding haunts, anggested to Colonel Talbot, R.E, the formation of a Morgeito Brigade on the linee laid down by Major Ross Two intelligent natives obtained from Colonel Stanton, the Moudir, were trained to recognize, under the supervision of Mr. Newlove, the laboratory assistant, mosquitoes, their egg, lar and page. Capt. Rivers, the setting 8.M.O., provided the equipment with which the mosquitoes were stacked in their larval stage. This was easily accomplished owing to the natore of their breeding places, claimed as follows:- 1. Welle, by far the most numerous and most large infected. 2. Bakia pits, both along the river bank and in certain gardens. 3. Garden tanke, practically confined to the riverfront. 4. Bath waste pita... 5. Permanent gardes pools, practically only found in the Palace gardens. 6. Zeers (native water filters) 7. River pools, ie, pools left in the banks by the falling Nile. 8. Steamer, boldr, tanks, water-closet cisterns and engine roce, also the bolds of wood and other barges. 9. Chance water collections as in old "ardals' ' or barges drawn up on the river bank, and from which speedy evaporation was prevented. Fortunately in Khartoon they had not to deal with any swamps, ditobes, permanent pools in the streets or near the bouros, empty cans, old bottles, broken crockery or other receptacles containing water for any length of time; at least there were none auch in the BonBon of 1903, when the rainfall during the ammer was trifling. Crude petroleum was used not only because it was cheaper, but because comparatively little of the well water is used for drinking purposes, the native portion of the population preferring to use wat direct from the Blue Nile Latterly, as a considerable quantity of refined petroleum had been stocked, a mixture of arade and refined was employed The former appears to be the more efficacious as it formed a denser film and one which lasted longer. The well water in Khartoum is for the most! part reserved for washing, dooking, and the use of animals. It was evident that the oiling of the walls would entail some hardship on their owners, but the above fact shows, what indeed proved to be the case, that it could be done without producing any great outory. The aser of an infected and oiled well generally managed to easily satisfy his wants from a neighboring uninfected and untreated water supply. Crude petroleum, as stated, is very effective if properly applied, and, moreover, makes the water so unsightly that none would toneh it, and then there was little risk of any poisoning from water so treated. As a matter of fact, no student was reported. The plan adopted was as follows: The men oohatitating the brigade began every morning to systematically visit all the water collrations in the towns, beginning on the river front and working backwards day by day till the whole town had been explored. They were provided with wide-mouthed bottles for taking samples, and instructed how best to proceed. In the afternoons, under the change of Me Newlove, the men again wont their rounds, the water collections were re-inspected, and any found to be infected were thoroughly oiled. In the case of welle with an average surface ses of 12 to 13 square feet about ene pistolerade petroleum was employed per well. This amount was probably in excess of that tually required, but by using it a reliable one was obtained. Eyringer, thongh good is the case of pools, were no use for welle, and it was found best to simply pour the oil straight down upon the water, which, as a rule, was found at a depth of from 25 to 30 feet. The sheiks of the various districts had orders to see that each "trained" water was not disturbed for forty-sight hours, after which time the users w.re allowed to remove the oil and take the water. This length of time amply sufficed, all the larva and pepe present being killed as shown by repeated investigations As a matter of fet the real lethal period was probably from about four to six hours, or even lear, but it was deemed advisable to let the oil remain for a time, as it has been shown that although aguito age way he laid on och oiled waters they will not undergo further development. It was of course impossible to make absolutely certain that these instructions were always faithfully obeyed, but in the great majority of cases the people did as they were told, and any that were refractory were at once reported to the S M. O., Captain Cummins, who straightway informed the Moudir, and the offenders were promptly brought to their More recently ellate have been directed to the closing of all naused wells, while, wherever possible, covers have been fixed on those in on and pampe introduced. Special methods were required in special places. In the Palace gardens pools had to be cleared of weeds and water-weeds, and in some in- stances were abolished. P.sh taken from the Blae Nile were tried both in wells and pools. In the former they speedily died, the water being too hard for them, but in pools con- taining river water they proved an access, thongh often using the larvae to disappear they too often disappeared themselves, owing to the depredations of natives or aquatic birds. Wherever pore blazers (native water filters) were inspected, and a notice both in English and Arabic was posted in the "Bodan Gastte," the official Government organ, drawing stton- tion to the 10's of thee earthenware jars a breeding places, and emphasizing the importance of having them empty! and cleaned at least twice in the week. Mr. Beadnell, of the Geological Survey, demonstrated that with a little care and trouble it was possible to get rid of mosquitoes from atesmers. A series of maps showing the distribution and the breeding habits of the different mosquitoes in Khartoum are given. It is of interest that the labors of the brigade have served to locate every well-in Khartoum, a matter of great importance in the event of any extensive outbreak of cholers or enteric fever. A series of tables are given to show the results obtained as illustrated by examinations of the wells before and after different periods of treatment. These statistics show that very considerable progress has been made: For the sake of argument, to show the benefits of treatment, the average number of larvae and pop in an infected water may be taken at one thousand, believed to err on the small side. According to the results obtained there is indicated a total destruction of 222,000 mosquitoes, granting that, if left alone, all the larvae and pope would have reached mato- rity. Nor does that represent in any way the eggs which were checked in their development. Again, say half of the above were females capable of laying from 20 to 400 eggs-piece- a moderate computation-and it will be apparent that the ranks of the winged host have undergone enormous depletion. This is further evidenced by the fact that latterly the infected walls have been found to harbor much smaller numbers of larvae than was the case at first, and by the experiences of residents and visitors. Certain water insects which prey on the larvae were found, but none were so voracious to yield hopes of being turned into a practical Account. More may possibly be expected from the discovery in the United States of a new para- site of the anopheline mosquitoes, and of a large warm which is claimed to render the female morq sito barren and induce disease in the insect. Mosquito work has not, however, been con- 6ned to Khartoum. From Kamals, Captain Tador, D.8.0., reports a great improvement both as regards morgnitoes and other noziose and annoying insects which pass their larval stages in water. In this connection, it is interesting to note that the Shillaks have a so-called manito plant." The leaves are dried and laid inside the roofs of their hats. The myth of the basil, if net that of the neen, having already been exploded, it is probable that this pre- Cautionary measure also gives a false sense of charity. A classification has also been made of mosquitoes found on the Blue and White Niles. The introduction of a flower cultivation in anggested at stations in the swamp regions of the White Nile. Apart from its water absorbing capacities the sun was of great value as an economic producer', the oil, seeds, and fiber all being neful. It has been successfully cultivated in the previously malarial stretches of the Mississippi Valley,and is known to grow well and rapidly in the Sudan. As an application against mosquito bites a mixture of equal parts of citronella oil and absolute alcohol was found not only to be the most effective application but also one pleasant to employ. In the review on Biting and Noxious le seats other than Mosquitoes' an account is given of a species of tre tre fly, captured by L. Colonel Griffith, D.8.0, on the Congo in the Bahr-el-Ghazal province when marching from Wan to Dem Zoter. It is this fly which carries the parasite so fatal to horses, donkeys, and certain other domestic animal and which was not previously known to have ecme further north than Rabek Exbabative researches are also recorded of the habits of the Asal or honey fly which has proved so destructive to the dors crop in Kasala, Sennar, and the Babr el Ghazal Although petroleum, naphthalene, and quas sis washes and sprays are effective, it is probable that the remedy will lie in the in- troduction of some insect which, like the lady bird beetles, feed greedily on there aphider or the encouragement of a special fungus which attacks and destroys them wholesale The report concludes with a review of the Mosquitoes of Egypt, the Sudan, and Atyminis based on material collected by Dr. Andrew Fa four, Director of the Wellcome Research laboratories, and to some extent by Captain Lyle Cummins, R. AM. C, Dr. Keatinge Meja Bold Row, C. B, the whole compiled classified, and illustrated by Mr. Fred. V Thetald, Vice Principal of the8 E Agricultural College

div.head:
NATIVE PRESS COMMENTS.
EGYPT'S FANATICISM
div.p: The Alexandria correspondent of El Zber'' has addressed the following open letter to the vernacular Press-The day before yesterday (13th inst.) was laid bare to you the motive of the anger of those concerned in the Deai-hwai incident. Why have you neglected to examine their revelations? Is it from patriotism or from religion 1 Do patriotism or religion permit use to keep silence over soch intrigues 1 Do they allow us to say that those concerned have hidden designs, when we know very well that they have no other object than to give a severe example, that after the Anglo French 'entente they are the absolute meters in the administration of the country, and that they have no need for the friendship of Germany or any other Power! Why does one not dark Lord Cromer know the names of the intrigeert! The law punishes each person. Why does not one ask him to point out the parties who are working for the wrecking of the Government so that they may be free to administer the country themselves as they wish and to parece a arbitrary rale Why, in short, does one not demand the names of those who light the fire of fanaticism and those papers who are doing stomach harm to Bar Pt 1 Boob persons should not remain in the country. What a curious thing! While Lord Cromer preaches to his Government the policy of mistrusting the Egyptians and puts himself on guard against the fanatioal parties, and while we, on the other band, forcibly relate the imputation, our confrères ery loudly, Yes, we have parties, and we glory before every sincere patriot in the princes and rich men who are included in those parties." It is in this way that they defend the interests of their nation, and those in authority take these declarations as a proof of the existence of fanaticism. From "Al Minbar of the 14th inet.Sir Edward Grey now acknowledges that the word fanaticism is open to criticism and that what exists in Egypt is more restlessness, This admission is an acknowledgment that the Egyptians now feel that their claims are not observed and that the English have usurped all the offices and ill-treat all thore under them and all Egyptians. Bir R. Grey said that the first time he heard of this restless feeling in Egypt was when Bogland and Prance 00- -cupid a Turkish island on account of the Macedonian crisis; and he then remarked, "Every time that there is trouble with Turkey its effects are felt by all the Mohamedans in the British Empire and in those countries occupied by Bogland." The truth of this will one day be fully realired by the English and they will then have to alter their treatment of the Mohame dans. Bagland will, indeed, be bound to do so when she feels the fall strength of the Pan- Islamio movement, which Lord Cromer regarde as a foolish attempt. But do those who criticize demand an ample proof than the declaration of Sir E. Grey that every trouble with Terkey affects all Mohamedass! We will go further than that and say that every trouble with the Mohamedans themselves is felt by their brethren the whole world over. This is our strength and our union. Would that it were even known by our brethren in China and would that they tried to strengthen this union with wisdom.

div.head: SEX AND APPENDICITIS
div.p: Carefully collected statistics, compiled by Professor Karrenstein, the well-known surgeon, of Berlin, go to prove that the received opinion that appendicitis is more frequent among men than among women is erroneous Hitherto, it has been generally accepted that the proportion of man to women affiliated with this disease is, as nearly as possible, two to one. Professor Karrenstein has examined the hospital lists of Berlin and Hamburg since 1874, and finds that the number of women treated for appendicitis falle very little below that of men In Hamborg the number of women was considerably in excess. The professor believes that as it is in Berlin and Hamborg so it is also in other large cities throughout the world.

div.head: BED-BUGS AND DISEASE
div.p: Dr. A. A. Giraalt has been able to trace some five hundred articles dealing in one connection or another with bed-beige, says the British Medical Journal," but very few of them have any relation to medicine or disease, and all of them leave the conviction that very little at all is really known about the habits and life history of Cimex leotalarins If it is dependent upon human blood for Its existence, as is commonly supposed, its poten tialities as a disease disseminator are greatly limited, but it is questionable if this be really the oase, and Dr. Giraalt's own limited experiments seem to indicate that the common bed-bag is indifferent as to the souros of blood which it obtains.

div.head: THE UNITED STATES AND INTERVENTION IN RUSSIA
div.p: An extraordinarily significant leading arti- ele, two celimas long, appears in the "New York Time" If the United States stood geographically, it says, in the relation of Germany or Austria it can hardly be doubted that the United States long ago would have been compelled by considerations of domestic peace and security to remonstrate with the Russian Government against the prolongation of the hopeless disor der in Rassis. The journal recalls the American intervention in Cabs, which, it alleges, was brought about partly by sympathy and partly because of conditions which "We could no long- er endure." Although the United States are very remote from Russia, nevertheless, the Times' continues, "oar interests are very imme diate, and with the lapse of time they may compel na to take such action as we might already have taken where was numbered among the European Powers." Admitting that foreign intervention in the domestic affairs of Rassis is not a matter of the immediate future, the "Times" insists that the principle of altimate intervention is not excluded by history, international law, or human reason or human probability. The time will coms, and it ought not to be far distant, when civilization will say to the Emperor: "You shall not make your palace a palabre of the peo ple's hopes, nor continue to flood our realus with your bleeding objects, fleeing from your assassin soldiery."

div.head: EGYPTIAN GLASS
div.p: In ancient Egypt the blowing of glass and the contriving of glass vessels mais vige fally 2,000 years before the Christian era. Ose of the tombs at Saqqara bears a represen. tation of glass blowing, considered to be the earliest known record of an art which, even at that early date, might have been quite an old established institution among the dwellers by the Nile. The ancient Egyptian glass work was usually opaque, and more or less brightly coloured. The vasos and other vessels were generally small Glaar beads of various colors were made, and one of these, still surviving, is repa ted to bear the name of Queen Hats, which, if tros, would date this very ancient bead back to about 1440 c. In the British Museum are many examples of early Egyptian glass, one of the most notable pieces being the Nineveh goblet, reputed to have left the hand of the glass- worker of ancient Berpt in or about the year 103 sc. From the Phoenicians and Egyptians the secrets of glassmaking spread to and were banned on by the Greeks, Etruscans and Bicilians

Tho experience of Mde. Beaudoin ought to be sufficient proof to any one of tho value of Peruna in cases of ca- tarrhal dyspepsia. If yon suffer from stomach catarrh in any of its various forms, give Peruna a fair trial, avoiding in tho meantime all such Indiscretions in diet as would tend to retard a cure, and yon will soon be rewarded by a normal appetite and healthy digestion.

For special directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life " a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Pe- ru na is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty five shillings.

div.head:
CORRESPONDANCE
UN CAMPING PARK MUNICIPAL
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de l'Egyptian Gazette." Notre Municipalité s'occupe en ce moment du nouveau sport américain, le Camping, consistant à camper en plein air, sous une tente.. Elle se montre outré de ce que des Samset des Jonathan's prétendent avoir eu les premiers l'idée de rajeunir cet antique procédé et de l'adapter à nos générations animées, comme eure hygiénique. Le fait est que les savants, érudits et doe- teurs (y compris les 13 médecins émargeant au budget pour une somme de 3.000 livres) qui président à nos destinées ont depuis longtemps, Avant même que les américains en parlent, pensé à faire du campement en plein air une institution d'utilité publique. Le trop plein de nos quartiers tuberculeux sera déversé sous des tentes, dans des pares immenses, Chatby, Fortifications, Moharrem Bey,ete. qui entouraient la ville comme d'une ceinture. Du même coup la question des loyers se trouvera résolue. Les rares habitants qui consentirent encore pendant quelque temps à hanter les habitations malsaines de la ville, ne tarderont pas, à la vue des mines réjouies de leurs anciens colocataires faisant du Camping, À abandonner, eux aussi, leurs coûteux appartements où les propriétaires, jadin si exigeants, se promènent seuls, comme des mes en peine. Dans le Camping park, il n'y aura pas de poussière, les matériaux de construction en 'étant bannis; le sol sera uniformément couvert d'un tapis de verdure, sur lequel joueront les petits enfants pendant que le père sorin à la chasse ou à la poche et que la mère vaquer aux soins du ménage. Voilà l'idyllique projet que rêvent nos (diles et que le gouvernement ne manquera pas d'apporter pour la plus grande joie des Alexan- drinks, Agréez, etc. Alexandrie, le 17 Août. TITYRE.

div.head: EN FAVEUR des CRETOIS
div.p: La Loge Hellénique "Alexandre le Grand" a exprimé dans sa dernière stance la vive douleur qu'elle ressent des décisions imposées à In Crète par les Puissances; elle a aussi protesté avec indignation contre les agressions brutales commises contre l'Hell/nisme en Roumanie et en Bulgarie; enfin elle a émis le voeu que le Ser. Grand Orient de Grèce Suprême Conseil du 33e fasse appel à tous les francs-maçons de l'Univers en faveur des Crétois.

div.head:
CIRCULAIRE H. DE VRIES ET BOUTIGNY
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 17 Août. A Londres, le Consolidé anglais est resté, hier encore, avarié à 88 1/8. L'Unifiée a clôturé en hausse de 1/4 à 104 3/4. La National Bank a perdu 14 à 26. L'Agricole et la D'air. sont demeurées inchangées à 9 7/8 et 16 7/8. La Delta Light est renseignée en réaction de 1/8 & 11 3/4. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 2 francs à 758 et la Banque d'Athènes Ifrane à 149. Ici, le marché des valeurs a été, ce matin, calme avec une certaine tendance à la lourdeur, par moments, sur les valeurs dirigeantes. Il y a eu, toutefois, assez d'animation sur divers autres titres et quelques-uns d'entre eux ont bénéficié d'une plus-value. La National Bank a Bini au même prix qu'hier, soit 26-26 1/16. L'Agricole s'est raffermie en clôture à 9 3/4-13/16. La Cassa di Sconto a réactionné à 226 l'action ancienne et 216 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Athènes a été échangée à 147 1/2 et la Banque d'Orient à 132 1/2. Le Comptoir Financier a encore molli à 6 1/2 l'action ancienne et 6 1/4 ts hou velle; la part de fondateur est revenue à 44-45. L'action Crédit Foncier a été moins ferme à 759-760; l'obligation à lots ancienne a m culé à 336. La Nile Land a gagné 1/4 de livre à 13 3/4- 13/16. La part de fondateur agricole du Nil a fléchi à 7 1/4 et l'action Union Foncière à 6 1/4. Les Allotments ont clôturé à 3 7/16-1/2. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux a été recherchée à 4 3/16-1/4. En bonne demande, la Brasserie des Pyramides est passée de 130 à 134-135. Les Héliopolis ont atteint 322; la part de fondateur est restée à 9 3/8. La part Bourse Kh4 Divialle du Caire a été négociée à 150-155, c'est-à-dire en hausse de 10 15 livres. Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, le Ninkovich ont clôturé à 17. Les Egyptian et les Upper Egypt se sont maintenus, sans affairés, à leurs prix d'hier.. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont débuté fermes à 3 9/16 pour atteindre 3 21/32 et finir à 3 1/2-9/16. On est sans informations certaines sur les explications qui ont dû être données à l'assemblée ordinaire tenue hier à Londres. Les Estates sont restés stationnaires A1 13/16-7/8; la part de fondateur a progressé 11 3/8-7/16, Les Walker and Mei Karachi ont fehi à 05/8-11/16 et les Constructions à 1 7/16, Les Khedivial Mail ont avancé à 35 sh. Et les New Egyptian à 29 heures. 3.. Ainsi que nous l'avions annoncé dans notre Circulaire de mardi passé, les gestionnaires de la Building Lands of Egypt Co. sont bel et bien convoqués en assemblée générale extraordinaire pour le 4 septembre prochain, au siège social & Alexandrie. L'ordre du jour porte: Communication des objections du liquidateur de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo) et d'une protestation télégraphique du censeur de la Building Lands concernant la validité des résolutions votées par les Assemblies dès 26 Juin et 18 Juillet 1906. Délibération sur lesdites résolutions. Dans le cas où la validité de ces résolutions ne serait pas admise par la délibération ci- Jésus: 1. Approbation, s'il y a lieu, de la fa- sion; 2. Pouvoirs aux administrateurs à l'effet de réaliser la fusion; 3. Augmentation du capital social par l'émission de 67,500 actions de £ 4 chacune et conditions de cette émission; nomination de deux administrateurs.
Hier,à la Bourse d'Alexandrie, l'action Bail- ding Lands a encore gagné 1/16 5 1/16; les Glymenopoulo sont restés à 1 3/8-13/32.
M. Périclès Glymenopoulo se trouve actuellement à Brides-les-Bains, en Savoie. On s'attend à ce qu'il rentre sans retard à Alexandrie.
Les recettes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 2e soft courant se sont chiffrées par LE. 447 contre 553 en 1905, soit en diminution de L.E. 106 pour l'exercice courant.
Les recettes totales depuis le ler Janvier 1906 ont atteint LE 22,172 contre 16,059, soit en augmentation de LE. 6,113,

Le bon sens nons commandait de ne pas oroire à la possibilité de la formation d'un syndicat sur août, et de la façon dont les choses se sont passées sur le marché dans la première partie de la semaine, en tant que cela con- perne la vieille récolte, nous semblions avoir raison; mais après les manoeuvres auxquelles nous assistons depuis hier et après le retrait des filières par certaines personnes, le doute n'est plus permis. Nous le regrettons sincère- ment tant pour le fait lui-même qu'à cause des intéressés, car c'est une gaffe de ples à ajouter à celles qui ont déjà été com- mises cette année; mais il a fallu que des non-professionnels se trouvassent engagés jus- qu'au cou pour arriver à une pareille com- binaison. Du reste, ce serait là la seule ex- case qu'ils pourraient faire valoir pour jus- tifier leur opération entreprise, certainement non de propos délibéré, mais bien parce qu'ils ont eu la main forcée et dans un bat de défense de leurs intérêts.-Et puis, en fin de compte, ils sont assez riches pour se payer os caprice, si caprice il y a eu, en cas où le coup, comme cela est probable, viendrait à rater. Ceci dit, passons à la revue du marché.

Au lieu de la fermeté à laquelle d'aucuns s'attendaient, c'est le calme et la faiblesse qui ont régné pendant la matinée de samedi, et comme résultat c'est une baisse de 1/8 que nous avons eu à enregistrer.

Lundi ayant été jour férié, la reprise des affaires n'a en lien que mardi et cette seconde éance a été marquée par un recul ultérieur de 1/3; mais, ce qui a é'é an comble et en même temps une véritable surprise, c'est la dégringolade de 19/32 qui s'est produite le lendemain et qui n'a en d'autre raison que l'offre de quelques milliers de cantars de flot- tant et la crainte d'une filière, plus grosse qu'on ne le disait, pour le jour suivant.

Au fond, cette tenue du marché était ridi- cale et indiquait de l'hésitation outrée de la part du groupe haossier; seulement, et fort heureusement pour lai, elle n'a pas duré, les circonstances étant venues à son secours. Ea effet, hier, aussitôt la filière émise, et elle n'a été que de cantars 18750, une demande a surgi tout à coup pour l'acût et tout naturel- lement les intéressés ont saisi la balle au bond pour réagir. L'août a été poussé presque d'un seal trait à 20 1/4, mais la constatation faite que tous ceux qui avaient aidé à chauffer le marché ne visaient qu'à se débarrasser de ce qu'ils avaient en contrats vieille récolte calma an peu l'ardeur du syndicat et nous valut une réaction à 19 7/8. Toutefois la clôture eut liea à 20 tallaris.
Ce matin, les baissier: s'étant terus tran- gailles, il a été facile aux intéressés à la hausse de soutenir les cours et comme finale de la semaine, c'est à 20 3/32 que l'Août s'est inscrit.

Comme résumé, c'est une nouvelle perte de 11/32 depuis vendredi dernier que l'Août subit, mais comme tendance, bien malin serait celui qui saurait l'indiquer. Da reste, les accapareurs de l'Août eux-mêmes ne savent pas ce qu'ils feront par la suite et, pour le moment, ils se contentent à mauvais jen de faire boane mire, en protestant contre les velléités d'égorgement qu'on leur prête et en disant qu'au fond ils De foot qu'une affaire commerciale, etc., etc. Certes, cela ne les empêchera pas de profiter da moindre découvert qui pourrait se pré- senter et la vérité est que si aujourd'hui ile

Teçoivent, c'est qu'il ne peuvent pas faire autrement. Quant à la liquidation finale, cela les regarde, mais, ce qui est incontestable, c'est que e temps leur manquera pour tout écouler avant que le nouvean coton ne vienne 138 entraver d'une façon sérieuse. Dans tous les cas, nous ne croyons pas qu'il y aura des ruines comme prix, car sur la base de 19 1/2 pour fully good fair, la filature anglaise, qui a des besoins pressants, a montré quelques dispositions aux achats. Elle n'avalera cer- tainement pas toute la quantité que le Byndicat pourra lui offrir, mais quand même et malgré la question de la qualité, une partie de re coton pourra trouver son placement auprès de la filature dans des conditions relati- vement raisonnables. Dans notre précédente revue, nous nous sommes suffisamment étendas sur cette affaire et nous ne voulons pas fatiguer le lecteur par des redites. Nous nous arrêtons donc pour aujourd'hui en résumant l'opinion générale qui prévaut à ce sujet en disant que quelles que soient les conditions dans lesquelles elle se terminers, elle sera tou jours une opération à perte.

La tenue de la nouvelle récolte a encore une fois é'é d'une fermeté extraordinaire; ni la baisse de l'Américain, ni l'abstention du commerce n'ont pu arrêter les haussiers et en définitive c'est à 17 1/2 que clôture le Novembre, soit avec an bénéfice de 1/16 sur Vendredi passé. C'est beau si l'on veut et poar sûr les rachats da découvert ont aidé à ce soutien, mais il semble que les haussiers négligent un pen trop ce qui se passe autour pour ne s'attrapper qu'à ce seul point. Contrairement à ce que nous pensions, il y a ea quelques résiliations de la part de la filature et plus d'an consommateur a déjà pris ses dispositions pour se mettre à l'américain. Pour le moment il ne s'agit que de cas isolés, mais la chose pourrait bien finir par s'étendre parmi les filateurs des numéros courants, si l'énorme écart actuel entre américain et égyptien se maintenait. La position locale ne suffit pas pour justifier la continuation du mouvement et il faut forcément tenir compte de la consommation: on a marché trop tôt et avec la baisse de l'américain les choses changent un peu d'aspect, car au bout du compte tout le monde ne file pas da fin et une partie de la consommation pent toujours être modifiée quand le filateur trouve son avantage à employer d'autres sortes et qu'il a le temps de s'y préparer. Nous pourrions bien avoir quelque surprise désagréable de ce côté-là.

Le résumé de Juillet de la Produce Association que nous reproduisons plus loin est très favorable à la récolte, mais quoique la plante soit dans de meilleures conditions que l'année dernière pour résister aux brouillards et aux intempéries qui pourraient survenir par la suite, il ne faut pas se fier d'une façon absolue aux belles apparences habituelles au mois de Jaillet. Oa a déjà signalé de Zagazig l'apparition d'un brouillard mardi de nier, mais il parait qu'il n'a été que de courte durée et n'a fait aucun mal. Dans tous les cas, nous ajoute- rons que si la température actuelle persiste, les chances sont pour une bonne réussite de la récolte.
Le marché du disponible a été absolument ca'me et c'est toujours la pénurie du choix qui entrave les affaires.

Quant aux prix, faute de pouvoir les con- stater d'une façon effective, c'est en se basant sur les cours des contrats qu'ils ont été établis dans la cote officielle de ce matin, d'cù la erbaisse de 3/8 sar les Mit Affifi.

Les Joannovich ont été par contre main etenus à leur niveau, précédent tandis que les provenances Haute Egypte ont été supprimées ( par suite de leur épuisement presque complet Les exportations de la semaine ont été une véritable déception avec leur total de 4,400. balles, contre 14,400 pour la même période en 1905, mais il convient de faire remarquer que cette semaine il n'y a pas eu de départ la pour Marseille et qu'il y a eu du retard dar su certains embarquements pour Liverpool. Cela & viendra la semaine prochaine; toutef is, il ne P faudrait pas se faire trop d'illusions sur ce g point, car même avec des expéditions un peu plus importantes pour le restant d'août, la campagne parait destinée à finir avec un arriéré de près de 200,000 cantars.
Liverpool a été tavorable et régulier commer demande pour les égyptiens disponibles et i comme moyenne les ventes journalières se sont à élevées à 500 bales.

Du côté des prix, cependant, les choses n'ont pes marché comme on aurait voulu, la cote de de jour nous montrant une baisse de 1/16 pour le spot qui est à 10 1/4, de 8/64 pour l'août tombé à 9 58/64 et de 10/64 pour le novembre qui recule à 8 51/64.

Pour les américains il y a eu aussi un peu plus d'activité, mais les cours, pour leur part, ont été encore plus maltraités que cenx de l'Egyptien et cela à cause de la baisse de New- York. En fait, le spot a reculé de 30 points à la cote de 5.68, le juillet-août de 29 points à 5.43 et l'octobre novembre de 25 points à 5.33.

L'effet du dernier rapport du bureau d'agri- culture a été de faire changer de position à Price et consorts qui seraient aujourd'hui à la baisse. Du reste, les nouvelles de la récolte sont satisfaisantes et cela peut justifier la volte face. Seulement, on semble aller trop vite dans la voie de la baisse et plus d'une personne sé- rieuse pense que le coton américain, à ce ni- vean, mérite un peu plus d'attention. L'état de l'industrie cotonnière est toujours prospère, et ceux qui sont à la tête du mouvement actuel peuvent bien sous peu tourner casaque epx- mêmes. Ils trouveront toujours un bon prétexte pour modifier leur attitude.
Graines de Coton
Le marché da disponible n'existant plus de fait, nous n'avons pour aujourd'hui à nous Occuper que des contrats.

Ceux ci ont été l'objet d'une bonne demande, dont la conséquence a été de faire monter Paoût à P.T. 71 1/4. Hall, qui se faisait tirer T'oreille pour acheter, a fini par payer jusqu'à £6.18/9, ce qui justifie nos cours.

La hausse en Angleterre est due à une amé lioration des tourteaux qui sont demandés. Comme exportations, la semaine a été plutôt insignifiante, mais pour le restant d'Août il y a des engagements est més à 190,000 ardebs environ. Si quelques nouvelles affaires ont en- core lieu, nous finirons presque sans stock à la fin du mois.
La nouvelle récolte a été très ferme, mais n'a suivi que lentement la hausse de l'ancienne. Dans tous les cas, les 3 mois sont à 64 3/4 et en bonne tendance.
Il nous faudrait toutefois un réveil de la demande anglaise pour les échéances éloignées Pour le moment elle a l'air de les négliger en maintenant sa cote à £65/- on £6.6/3 pour ele Novembre-Janvier.
SECTION COTONNIÈRE

Résumé des réponses reçues en Juillet 1906: La température pendant le mois de Juillet a été très favorable à la récolte; les fortes cha- leurs ont largement profité aux cotonniers et lear ont fait regagner, presque partout, le retard précédemment signalé.
L'aspect des plantes est sain et vigoureux. La floraison est abondante, des noix se sont formées partout et semblent sassi nombreuses que l'année dernière à la même époque.

On a encore constaté la présence des vers et quelques rares apparitions de papillons, mais partout les mesures prises pour leur extirpation ont en plein suocès et la forte chaleur a été anesi d'an secours précieux.
Dans le Nord da Bébéra seul, il a eu quel- ques plaintes au sujet des dégâts causés par les vers, sans grande importance toutefois.
L'eau a été suffisante et a permis une irrigs- tion régulière dans toutes les provinces.
Les informations de la Haute-Egypte et do Fayoum sont satisfaisantes et il n'y a pas en
de vers.
Da Fayoum on dit qu'il y a toujours un peu de retard, mais qu'il est partiel.
Alexandrie, le 9 Août 1906.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 10 Août 1906.

Nous avons eu cette semaine une reprise à se laquelle peu de personnes s'attendaient. Le mois d'août, en effet, correspond à la période nnuelle de calme plat, sans haut ni bas bien prononcés: le relèvement de la cote, accompa gné d'an mouvement assez intense de transsc- tions à cette époque de l'année, & done surpris m le plus grand nombre.

Cependant, à la bourse, comme ailleurs, tout th asa raison d'être. En l'occarrence, la hauese ne représente qu'une réaction. Par suite d'alarmes injustifiées on était tombé ces temps derniers à des cours très bas, correspondant presque à un dixième de perte pour les valears les plus solides. C'était d'abord l'incident de Denchawi dont on craignait les suites, pais les affaires de Russie qui semblaient se compliquer d'ane façon inextricable, enfin un malaise général inspirant de la méfiance aux capitalistes et les écartant de la corbeille.

Maintenant qu'ils ont pu s'apercevoir que A l'Angleterre avait tout prévu pour mainte nir ici le bon ordre, les égyptiens reprennent peu à peu le cours de leurs transactions; en Russie la paix semble aussi renaitre par la répres-t sion et le bruit d'une entrevue du roi Edouard avec le kaiser fiait de calmer toutes les appré- hensions. Tels sont les principaux motifs qu'on allègue pour le réveil de notre marché. Mais il y a pour l'amélioration des cours une raison bien plus simple: une baisse exagérée en face d'ane abondance croissante de espitaux. Une foule de circonstances ont d'ailleurs concoura favoriser le mouvement haussier: l'Amérique ayant momentanément cessé de drainer les capitaux européens, ceux-ci doivent naturelle- ment chercher un autre emploi ; les cotons étant en hausse, les gains réalisés se déversent en partie dans la corbeille des valears; enfin, le taux d'oscompte privé vient d'être réduit en Angleterre à 3%, tandis que le Consolidé se relève à 88 1/2. A Paris il y a également hausse de la rente et des valeurs égyptiennes. Voilà plus qu'il n'en faut pour expliquer la reprise de ces derniers jours. C'est une simple réaction. Il n'est pas vraisemblable, à cette époque de l'antée, qu'il y ait un mouvement, saivi et important à la hausse. Il faut pour cela attendre, comme toujours, la fin des vacan- ces et la rentrée des capitalistes d'Europe. Tout su plas y aura-t-il une légère accentua tion de la reprise pour certains titres encore trop dépréciés.
Sur une cinquantaine de valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle de la Bourse d'Alexandrie 28 sont en hausse, 7 seulement en baisse et 24 restent stationnaires aux cours antérieur.

Les fluctuations les plus remarquables sont: à la hausse, la National Bank qai gagne 5/8, la Ramleh Railway 5/8, les Nangovich Hotels 1 livre 1/16, la Delta Land 7/16, la Nile Land 1/2, la part de fondatear Comptoir 3 livres 1/2, et l'Union Foncière 9/32; à la baisse, les pertes sont insignifiantes.

On attribue la bausse considérable de la Delta Land au découvert d'une importante maison du Caire qui a da se couvrir au plus vite. Cette coïncidence n'aurait pas été étran- gère à la reprise générale en donnant au marché un aspect animé qu'il avait perda depuis long- temps et en faisant croire à l'entrée en scène du graud mouvement d'automne. Ainsi que nous l'avons dit dans notre dernière chronique, c'est jeudi prochain que doit avoir lieu l'as- semblée générale de la Delta Land pour examiner le bilan et approuver, s'il y a lieu, les résolutions prises à l'assemblée extraordi- naire da 19 jaillet dernier.

Pour le Comptoir Financier et Commercial nous avons donné les causes da relèvement des cours dans notre dernière chronique. En ce qui concerne l'Union Foacière, il y a une excellente opération conclue dernièrement par cette société et consistant dans la vente de 130 feddans de terrains à Dar el Bakar pour la somme de L.E. 10,000; ce qui re- présente un bénéfice de L.B. 5,450 sur le prix d'achat. Cette même société vient d'acheter ALE 45'e teddan 400 faddans de terrains qui valent en leur état actuel L.E. 60 le feddan.

La Delta Light est essentiellement ane retardataire dans les mouvements de bourse; ainsi, tandis que la plupart des valeurs, y com- pris les banques, sont en reprise marquée, elle 5 reste stationnaire à 11 9/ 6, en dépit de ses bonnes recettes.

L'Administration des chemins de fer est en train d'élaborer un tarif spécial pour le trans- port des marchandises appartemant à la société des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte, ainsi que les clauses du contrat de cession des voies ferrées a de la Compagnie. En attendant, le cours de la avaleur tombe de fr. 26 à 25.

Le conseil d'administration du Crédit Fon- acier Egyptien vient d'appeler le deuxième quart sur les actions de la société soit 125 fr. par titre, en deux versements égaux à effectuer, le premier du ler an) 6 septembre 1906 et le second du 2 au 8 janvier 1907.

Conformément à la décision prise à son Assemblés générale extraordinaire da 7 Juillet dernier, la Banque d'Athères va porter son capital de 20 à 40 millions de drachmes par la création de 200,000 actions nouvelles d'ane D valeur nominale de 100 drachmes: 100,000 de ces actions seront remises aux porteurs des 150,000 actions du Crédit Industriel de Grèce, en échange de leurs propres titres; les autres 100,000 seront offertes en souscription, jonis- sance da ler Janvier 1907, au prix de dr. 152.50 aux actionnaires actuels de la Banque d'Athè nes, dans la proportion de 1 action nouvelle pour 2 anciennes; les porteurs ont en outre le droit de souscrire, sous réserve des possibili és d'attributions, une quantité supplémentaire de titres à leur convenance.

En général, on s'attend pour la semaine prochaine à une accentuation du mouvement de hausse. Mais nous ne ore yons pas que ce mouvement doive prendre de grandes propor- tions jusqu'à la rentrée d'automne.

div.head: MOUNT TROODOS CYPRUS
div.p: A limited number of paying guests can be received by a Lady daring the Summer Months. Cyprus is 24 hours by sea from Port Said. Troodos 6,406 feet above the sea is a delightful and healthy place amongst the pine forests where the troops and Government Officials spend the hot season
Terms 21/2 Guineas per week. For farther particulars apply to Miss YOUNG, Nikosia, or to the Editor

Further Particulars. POSITION. The pine covered slopes of Mount Troodos where Miss You NO has a camp, are about 6406 feet above the sea ; the troops stationed in Cyprus and the Principal Government Officials live there during the hot season from about June till October.

Routes. Troodos is about 55 miles from the port of Limassol from which there is a good carriage road to Platres 31 m. Beyond Platres the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road from the Capital. Nicosia, by which persons going from that side of the Island drive all the way (about 16 miles).
Climate. The climate is very dry and healthy; ii the daytime it is delightful ; the nights, especially afte the end of August, are often rather cold.

Dress. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills, and ladies should be provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, but it is advisable to have some brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen dresses which do not shew dust stains as the washing is not first rate. A warm woolen "coat and skirt" costume is also indispensable.
Rides. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are too steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hired for the season.
Expeditions. Places of interest to lie reached on mule or pony Iwtek are Kykko Monastery. Kalopanaioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
Games. There is a Tennis Club with two good Courts, there are also one or two private tennis and croquet grounds.
Church. An English Church Service is held twice on Sundays at the Regimental Recreation Room.
Water. The water supply is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome.
Money. Drafts on the Imperial Ottoman Bank and English gold and notes accepted
By June the railway which runs from Famagusta to Nicosia will lx* extended to within 20 mile of Nikosia. 28216-12a-2

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
